ContentClassification.TableReference: Joshua Milne, “A Treatise on the Valuation of Annuities and Assurances on Lives and Survivorships; on the Construction of Tables of Mortality; and on the Probabilities and Expectations of Life Volume II, Chapter XI,” (London, 1815) p. 404-61, reprinted by Nelson and Warren, Inc, “Principal Mortality Tables, Old and New”, (St. Louis, MO, 1957) p. 2-3
ContentClassification.TableDescription: Death rates based on population data of Carlisle, United Kingdom. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 104.
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Description: Milne took as the basis of his calculations the Carlisle bills of mortality, which had been prepared by Dr. John Heysham. Dr. Heysham kept a record of the annual births, marriages, diseases, and deaths in two parish towns of Carlisle for ten years (to 1788), including a census of the inhabitants in 1780, and again in 1788. These statistics were published with remarks on them at Carlisle in 1797. Although using only a few lives, Milne's table proved remarkably accurate and is still held in high esteem for some purposes. Methodology: The Carlisle Table was the first mortality table graduated so as to smooth out accidental variations from age to age; unlike The Northampton (SOA table identify 250), it was constructed from census returns as well as records of deaths. Milne’s complex calculations were documented in a later publication “On the method used by Milne in the construction of the Carlisle Table of Mortality”, Journal of the Institute of Actuaries, Vol. 24 (1883), p.110–129. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 11/2012.

MetaData.TableDescription: Death rates based on population data of Northampton, United Kingdom. Basis: Age at Death. Minimum Age: 0. Maximum Age: 104.
